channel.title: Right Clicking - Windows 7
channel.description:
Hi, Yesterday i was doing the general bit of cleaning and quickly wiped down my keyboard, but now my right click wont work on my mouse, I dont know what i've done so i don't know how to fix it... can anybody help, this is a picture of my mouse
[img]http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/41EmUiOBldL.jpg[/img]

item.title: Right Clicking - Windows 7
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Greeny, post:17, topic:333600”]Cheers for the picture of your mouse, I’d completely forgotten what the right-button looked like.

Luckily your picture has allowed me to successfully diagnose your mouse’s problem;
it’s not plugged in.

Maybe you unplugged your keyboard and mouse when you cleaned, but only remembered to put the keyboard back.[/quote]

HAHAHAHAHAHA

Read full topic

item.title: Right Clicking - Windows 7
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Cheers for the picture of your mouse, I’d completely forgotten what the right-button looked like.

Luckily your picture has allowed me to successfully diagnose your mouse’s problem;
it’s not plugged in.

Maybe you unplugged your keyboard and mouse when you cleaned, but only remembered to put the keyboard back.

item.title: Right Clicking - Windows 7
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

OK, you ignored the solution.

as I said its a bad context menu handler, maybe it just corrupted, its windows things happen.

try: http://www.nirsoft.net/utils/shexview.html and disable all non-microsoft ones one-by-one.

Read full topic

item.title: Right Clicking - Windows 7
item.dc:creator: @WowILikeToCode WowILikeToCode
item.description:
@WowILikeToCode wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:9, topic:333600”]The problem is caused by a bad context menu handler.

check in the registry:

HKCR \*\shellex\contextmenuhandlers

there will be several HKCR entries, AllFileSystemObjects, Folder, Directory.

find one that you added recently, and remove it.
keep removing them one-by-one (remember the information, or do a backup first) to find out which one is broken.[/quote]

I don’t understnad, i havent edited anything all i did was wipe a cloth along my keyboard and now i have to hold my mouse down for 10 seconds to get it to right click.

Read full topic

item.title: Right Clicking - Windows 7
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

The problem is caused by a bad context menu handler.

check in the registry:

HKCR \*\shellex\contextmenuhandlers

there will be several HKCR entries, AllFileSystemObjects, Folder, Directory.

find one that you added recently, and remove it.
keep removing them one-by-one (remember the information, or do a backup first) to find out which one is broken.

Read full topic

item.title: Right Clicking - Windows 7
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

Then try looking on the control panel like mwiebelhaus said.

Did you try right clicking on IE? If it works on IE then there’s a registry key you need to modify…

Read full topic

item.title: Right Clicking - Windows 7
item.dc:creator: @WowILikeToCode WowILikeToCode
item.description:
@WowILikeToCode wrote:

i tried using my mouse that plugs into the propper mouse port and that does the same, and i have now worked out if i hold my right click down for 10 seconds it works, but this isnt exactly usefull for me

Read full topic

item.title: Right Clicking - Windows 7
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

mwiebelhaus:

Well maybe your mouse is just a piece of shit and now it has broke. Look at thin the fucking wire is. Either way there is mouse options in the control panel look at those.

The mouse doesn’t exactly use a parallel cable, so any damage to the USB cable would affect the entire mouses functionality, not just one button.

Read full topic
